78901245_syn_1:
Indication: Alpha-1 Emphysema (LLL).
Proc: BLVR LLL (Teaching).
Actions:
- Chartis: CV Negative.
- Valve selection: 5.5mm (LB6), 4.0mm (LB8-10).
- Fellow placed valves. Repositioning required for first.
- Final: Complete occlusion.
Plan: Admit.
78901245_syn_2:
PROCEDURE NOTE (TEACHING): 69F with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. 
SUPERVISION: Dr. Williams supervising Dr. Lee (Fellow). 
DETAILS: Chartis assessment of LLL indicated absent collateral ventilation. Valve sizing was performed based on CT. The fellow deployed valves in LB6 and LB8-10. Correction of valve orientation was performed under guidance. 
OUTCOME: Successful lobar occlusion confirmed.
78901245_syn_3:
Coding: 31647 (Valve Placement), 31634 (Chartis). 
Note: Teaching physician present. 
Lobe: Left Lower Lobe.
Details: Chartis confirmed negative CV. Valves placed in LB6 and LB8-10.
78901245_syn_4:
Procedure: BLVR (Teaching)
Attending: Dr. Williams
Fellow: Dr. Lee
Steps:
1. Airway exam.
2. Chartis LLL: Negative.
3. Measured bronchi.
4. Placed 2 valves (LB6, LB8-10).
5. Had to fix the first one, second one perfect.
Plan: Admit.
78901245_syn_5: sharon kim here for valves she has alpha 1. i let the fellow dr lee do the procedure. we checked the lll with chartis it was good. fellow had a little trouble with the first valve had to move it but got it eventually. second one was fine. lobe is sealed up. good teaching case.
78901245_syn_6: Procedure Date: [REDACTED]. Patient: Sharon Kim. Procedure: BLVR LLL. Teaching case with Fellow. Chartis Assessment: Target LLL, NEGATIVE CV. Valve Deployment: LB6 (5.5mm), LB8-10 (4.0mm). First valve required repositioning. Final bronchoscopy: Both valves well-positioned, complete occlusion confirmed. Patient Outcome: Tolerated well.

78901245_syn_8: This was a teaching case with Dr. Lee. We treated Ms. [REDACTED] for her Alpha-1 emphysema. We confirmed the left lower lobe was a good target with the Chartis system. Dr. Lee placed the valves. We had to adjust the first one to get a perfect seal, but the second one went in easily. The lobe is completely blocked off now.
78901245_syn_9:
Procedure: Bronchoscopic lung volume reduction (Educational).
Subject: [REDACTED]-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
Method: Chartis evaluation. Deployment of endobronchial valves in LLL. One valve required realignment.
Result: Total lobar obstruction.
78901245:
Procedure Date: [REDACTED]

Patient: [REDACTED] | DOB: [REDACTED] | Age: 69 | MRN: [REDACTED]  
Institution: [REDACTED]
Primary Operator: Dr. Jason Lee, MD (PGY-5 Fellow)
Supervising: Dr. Marcus Williams, MD, FCCP
Anesthesia: Dr. Sandra Lopez, MD

CASE SUMMARY:
69-year-old woman with severe alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency emphysema (PiZZ genotype), lower lobe predominant disease pattern.

TEACHING POINTS REVIEWED PRE-PROCEDURE:
1. Alpha-1 patients often have basilar predominant disease (unlike smoking-related emphysema)
2. Valve selection sizing based on CT measurements  
3. Chartis interpretation and decision-making
4. Complete vs. incomplete fissure implications

PRE-PROCEDURE CHECKLIST:
☑ Consent obtained and witnessed
☑ Sedation plan reviewed with anesthesia
☑ CT images loaded on workstation
☑ Valves available (multiple sizes)
☑ Chartis system prepared and tested
☑ Fluoroscopy operational
☑ Emergency equipment checked

PROCEDURE WALKTHROUGH:

STEP 1: Airway Assessment
Fellow performed systematic examination with attending supervision. Appropriate technique demonstrated for complete inspection.

STEP 2: Chartis Assessment  
Target: Left Lower Lobe
- Catheter advanced to LLL
- Balloon inflated to create seal at LLL orifice
- Baseline flow and resistance measured
- Results: Flow decay to <30mL/min = NEGATIVE CV
Teaching point: This indicates absent collateral ventilation and favorable for valve therapy

STEP 3: Bronchial Measurement & Valve Selection
CT-based measurements reviewed:
- LB6: 6.8mm diameter → 5.5mm valve selected
- LB8-10: 5.2mm diameter → 4.0mm valve selected

STEP 4: Valve Deployment (Fellow performed with guidance)
- First valve (LB6): Required repositioning due to initial incomplete seal. Good learning opportunity regarding deployment technique.
- Second valve (LB8-10): Successful first attempt with excellent technique
- Final bronchoscopy: Both valves well-positioned, complete occlusion confirmed

TEACHING POINTS POST-PROCEDURE:
1. Valve repositioning is common and not a complication
2. Visual confirmation of complete lobar occlusion is essential
3. Post-procedure care including steroid/antibiotic prophylaxis rationale
4. Expected timeline for symptom improvement (4-6 weeks typically)

FELLOW ASSESSMENT:
Demonstrated good procedural skills. Area for improvement: Pre-deployment assessment of valve orientation. Overall: Progressing well in BLVR competency.

PATIENT [REDACTED]: Tolerated well, stable, admitted for observation per protocol.

Marcus Williams, MD, FCCP
Program Director, Pulmonary/Critical Care Fellowship
Temple University Hospital
Philadelphia, PA
